Ronco” CINDECA (CONICET-CIC-UNLP) Facultad de Ciencias Exactas Universidad Nacional de La Plata Calle 47 N 257 AJK La Plata B1900 Argentina Quinoxalines and their derivatives are of great value in the chemical and biological sciences. These compounds are found in dyes, agrochemicals, and are used as building blocks of drugs for the treatment of different diseases. Quinoxalines and their derivatives are synthesized by a heterogeneous catalysis procedure that involves the condensation of 1,2-dicarbonyl compounds with aromatic 1,2-diamines in an aprotic organic solvent at low temperature, in the presence of an acid catalyst composed of tungstophosphoric acid immobilized on mesoporous silica nanoparticles. The reaction process is very simple and the catalyst, besides being very active and selective, can be easily isolated from the reaction medium and reused in subsequent reactions without considerable loss of activity. Quinoxalines are obtained in short reaction time with excellent yields and high purity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Nanoparticles Mesoporous silica Tungstophosphoric acid Quinoxalines 1 Introduction Nitrogen heterocycles are essential chemicals present in pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals, among others. As an alternative to the classical manufacturing from fossil resources, new reaction routes to prepare heterocyclic nitrogen compounds from biomass have been developed [1]. Particularly quinoxalines and their structural homologues are organic compounds of great importance, since they have a wide spectrum of applications; for this reason, a large number of methods have been reported for their synthesis. The quinoxaline substructure is considered to be an important core for the construction of drugs that are used in different types of cancer treatments due to their potential activity as protein kinase inhibitors. Therefore, these molecules are of great relevance to medicinal chemistry [2–4]. For more than three decades, quinoxalines and their derivatives have been developed as building blocks for the construction of anticancer structures. For example, triostin A is an antineoplastic agent that prevents the development, growth, or proliferation of malignant tumor cells [5]; (2R) 2-[4-(6-chloroquinoxaline-2-yl-oxy)phenoxy]propanoic acid [6] is a topoisomerase II inhibitor (an enzyme capable of acting on DNA topology); and (quinoxalin-2-yl)-benzenesulfonamide derivatives have potent anticancer activity against human liver cancer cell [7]. Furthermore, the structure of quinoxaline is a basic part of the molecular skeleton of different antibiotics, such as echinomycin, which inhibits the growth of gram-positive bacteria and has activity against diverse tumors [8]. Quinoxalines and their derivatives are also employed as dyes [9], electroluminescent materials [10], organic semiconductors [11], and chemically controlled switches [12]. The synthesis of 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline by the classical method reported by Hinsberg and König has been known since 1894 [13]. This process is based on the double condensation of a 1,2-dicarbonyl compound (e.g., benzil) with a 1,2-diamine, using ethanol or acetic acid as solvent, in a reaction time of approximately 12 h. Under these conditions, the yields are usually moderate [14]. Due to the importance and versatility of 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline, an attempt has been made to improve this protocol, using other solvents such as toluene, acetonitrile, tetrahydrofuran, or formic acid [15], by microwave activation [16] or by carrying out the reaction in solid phase [17]. Another tandem process involves the reaction between α-hydroxyketones and 1,2-diamines. At the first stage, it is necessary to carry out the oxidation of an α-hydroxyketone and subsequently, the condensation of the 1,2-dicarbonyl compound thus formed with a 1,2-diamine takes place. Different metallic precursors have been used for this transformation, such as Pd(OAc)2, RuCl2(PPh3)3TEMPO, MnO2 [18], zeolites [19], DABCO [20], among others [21]. In general, the aforementioned synthetic methods have some drawbacks, such as harmful reaction conditions, low yields, long reaction times, tedious separation procedures, and formation of various by-products. The main inconvenience of homogeneous methods is based on the fact that the catalyst cannot be recovered and reused. For this reason, the search for new heterogeneous processes using recyclable solid catalysts is of current interest. For several decades, heteropolyacids (HPAs) have been employed as catalysts in different reactions. HPAs are more active and produce better yields than conventional inorganic catalysts, are noncorrosive and environmentally benign, because they can be separated and reused in a simple way [22]. HPAs have been extensively used in the synthesis of organic compounds and in the conversion of biomass into chemicals and fuels [23–26]. However, due to their low specific surface area (∼x223C 7 m2/g) and to increase their catalytic activity and facilitate their recovery, HPAs must be associated with materials with a high surface area. In this work, we describe the synthesis of quinoxalines and their derivatives using mesoporous silica nanoparticles (SNPX) impregnated with tungstophosphoric acid (WPA) as reusable solid catalyst. The catalytic performance of the samples was evaluated in the one-pot reaction between 1,2-phenylenediamine and diphenylethanodione (benzil) to obtain the corresponding 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline (DPQX) using toluene as solvent at 20 °C (Scheme 1 ). The reaction times (2–10 h) depend on the aromatic ring substituent, and DPQX is obtained in excellent yield (94−98%). UV-Vis spectrophotometry was employed for DPQX quantification since this compound absorbs at λ = 345 nm. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of mesoporous silica nanoparticles SNPXs were synthesized by hydrolysis of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma Aldrich, 98%), using lysine (Sigma Aldrich, 98%) as catalyst, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Sigma Aldrich, ≥ 99%) as mesopore former, styrene (Sigma Aldrich, ≥ 99%) as template precursor, cyanovaleric acid (CVA, Sigma Aldrich, ≥ 98%) as styrene polymerization initiator, and octane (Sigma Aldrich, 98%) as nonpolar medium. In a typical procedure for preparing the silica / template particles, first 0.70 g of CTAB was dissolved in 216 mL of distilled water at 60 °C in a balloon. After obtaining a limpid solution, octane (64 mL), styrene (84 mg), lysine (0.16 g), TEOS (71 g), and CVA (181 mg) were added. The reaction was carried out for 3 h under nitrogen atmosphere at 60 °C. Then, the suspension was allowed to cool to room temperature. The system was left to stand for 18 h and finally, the solid was separated by centrifugation. The obtained material was washed with fresh ethanol, and then styrene was removed by heat treatment at 500 °C, for 3 h. Some samples were also prepared by changing the octane/water ratio (OCT/W) between 1.2 × 10−3 and 0 5 (v/v), keeping the amount of CVA constant and a styrene/water ratio (STY/W) equal to 0.39 or 10 (w/v), in order to analyze the effect of the variables on the properties of the materials obtained. 2.2 Synthesis of SNPX#WPA catalysts The impregnation of SNPX materials was performed by contacting, at 25 °C, 2.1 g of the solid with 0.9 g of WPA (H3PW12O40) dissolved in 9 mL of water-ethanol (1:1 v/v) solution to get a WPA concentration of 30% (w/w) in the SPNX#WPA materials. The SNPX support and the water-ethanol solution were kept in contact until dry. Then, the solids were dried at 70 °C and calcined at 200 °C for 2 h under air atmosphere. The method employed to determine the WPA content is described in supplementary material [27]. 2.3 Sample characterization Specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (VP), and pore size distribution (PSD) were obtained by nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements. The size and morphology of the SNPX#WPA materials were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The prepared samples were also evaluated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and 31P magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR) spectroscopy using Bruker IFS 66 and Bruker MSL-300, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to determine the structural characteristics. The acid strength and the number of acid sites were estimated from the n-butylamine potentiometric titration results (see details of characterization techniques in supplementary material). 2.4 Catalytic test and suitable synthesis of quinoxalines 2.4.1 General All reagents were obtained from Aldrich and were used without further purification. All products were identified by comparison of their physical and spectral data with those of the reported samples. The yields refer to isolated products. Melting points were measured in sealed capillary tubes and were uncorrected. The 13C NMR and 1 H NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature on Bruker AVANCE 300 MHz spectrometer using TMS as internal standard. 2.4.2 Catalytic test to optimize the reaction conditions A mixture of benzil (0.5 mmol), 1,2-phenylenediamine (0.6 mmol), catalyst (0.5% mmol of WPA relative to benzil, total mass of catalyst = 24 mg), and toluene (12.5 mL) was stirred at 20 °C for the appropriate time. The advancement of the reaction and quantification were carried out following the variation in the intensity of the adsorption band located at λ = 345 nm, where the reaction product absorbs, by means of UV-Vis Perkin Elmer Lambda 35 equipment, using a calibration curve. 2.4.3 General procedure for the synthesis of quinoxalines A mixture of the corresponding ethanodione (0.5 mmol), diamine (0.6 mmol), catalyst (SNP4#WPA, 0.5% mmol), and 12.5 mL of toluene was stirred at 20 °C for the appropriate time. Completion of the reaction (to achieve complete ethanodione conversion) was indicated by TLC. The reaction blend was filtered to separate the catalyst, which was washed with toluene (2 × 3 mL). The combined organic extracts were washed with water (2 × 5 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and evaporated in vacuum. The obtained solid was recrystallized from ethanol. 2.4.4 Recycling of the catalyst After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was removed by filtration, washed carefully with toluene, dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 4 h, and reused following the same procedure. 2.5 Electronic density determination The electronic density of nitrogen atoms in the amines and carbon atoms in dione compounds was determined after optimization of their conformation (by means of the “model build” modulus available in HyperChem 5.0). Each molecular structure was preoptimized with the molecular mechanics force field (MM+) procedure, and further refined by the semiempirical method PM3 (Parametric Method-3), with a gradient norm limit of 0.01 kcal Å−1. 2.6 Characterization of representative compounds 6-Methyl-2,3-diphenylquinoxaline (b): 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.00 (d, J= 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.88 (dd, J= 1.5, 0.9 Hz, 1H), 141.16, 140.93, 139.63, 135.00, 132.64, 131.83, 131.80, 131.72, 131.69, 128.60, 127.88, 115.63, 115.34, 21.93. 3 Results and discussion Textural and acidic properties of SNPX#WPA catalysts and bulk WPA are presented in Table 1 . For comparison, Table 1, entry 7, also shows the mentioned characteristics of bulk WPA supported on commercial silica, SiO2#WPA (Silica Grace, SBET 311 m2/g, Dp ∼x223C 4 nm). The isotherms of SNPX#WPA samples can be assigned as type IV, (with H1 hysteresis loops) characteristic of mesoporous materials (see Fig. S3 in supplementary material). The main features of isotherms resemble those of the SNPX used as support. It was observed that WPA incorporation did not produce a significant change in the textural properties and morphology of the SNPX used as support. However, SNPX#WPA specific surface area decreased by about 25%−30% (Table S1, supplementary material). The reduction of the SBET values can be due to the small specific surface area of bulk WPA (∼x223C 7 m2/g). PSD reveals the existence of small mesopores (centered in the range 5–7 nm) in the SNP1#WPA and SNP2#WPA materials (Table 1, entries 1and 2). On the other hand, additionally to small mesopores (centered in the 6–9 nm range) SNP3#WPA, SNP4#WPA, and SNP5#WPA solids present large mesopores (centered in the 28–37 nm range) (Table 2 , entries 3–5). We have reported [27] that under the reaction conditions used, CTBA and polystyrene participate mainly as template of small and large mesopores, respectively. The XRD patterns of SNPX#WPA samples show wide signals at around 8, 19, and 27° 2θ (Fig. 1 ), overlapped with those of the amorphous silica. Neither the diffraction lines assigned to H3PW12O40•23H2O nor those ascribed to H3PW12O40•6H2O (two of the main WPA crystalline phases) are present in the XRD patterns. These results indicate that WPA could be highly dispersed on the support as a noncrystalline phase. The high surface area and mesopore size (Dp higher than 5.9 nm) facilitate the dispersion of WPA species (mean size ∼x223C 1.2 nm) into the SNPX pore structure. Besides, having in mind that the cross-sectional area of the WPA anion is 1.13 nm2 [28], we estimated that the percentage of total surface area of SNPX materials covered by WPA in SNPX#WPA solids was lower than 35%. On the other hand, the FT-IR spectra of SNPX#WPA samples (see Fig. S4, supplementary material) show the main bands of WPA (Table 2, entries 1–5) overlapping those of the silica nanoparticles used as support [29]. Moreover, neither the characteristic bands of the dimeric species [P2W21O71]6− nor those of the lacunary anion [PW11O39]7− appear [30]. These results demonstrate that the [PW12O40]3− is the main species in SNPX#WPA materials, so we can conclude that the Keggin structure of WPA is maintained during impregnation and calcination. The 31P magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance spectra of SNP1#WPA and SNP4#WPA samples (Fig. 2 b and 2c, respectively) show two wide peaks at −15.2 and −15.0 ppm, attributed to [PW12O40]3− interacting with H+(H2O)2 species (line width 0.08 ppm) and [H3-XPW12O40](3–X)− (line width 0.12 ppm), respectively [31,32]. In the case of hydrated WPA (H3PW12O40•6H2O), the first peak appears at −15.3 ppm. The downfield shift with respect to WPA was assigned to the electrostatic interaction between the anions and the Si-OH2 + groups in SNPX#WPA samples. An analogous behavior was suggested for the interaction of WPA with ZrO2 and TiO2 [32]. The area under the curve obtained by potentiometric titration provides an estimation of the number of acid sites (NAS). The titration curves of SNP1#WPA and SNP4#WPA samples (Fig. 3 ) indicate a higher presence of NAS (138 and 140 meg n-butylamine/g, respectively) than SNP1 and SNP4 solids used as support (27 and 24 meg n-butylamine/g, respectively). SNP2#WPA, SNP3#WPA, and SNP5#WPA samples have similar NAS values (136, 139, and 142 meg n-butylamine/g, respectively). However, the Ei values of SNP1#WPA and SNP2#WPA materials (574 and 474 mV, respectively) are higher than those of SNP3#WPA, SNP4#WPA, and SNP5#WPA (292, 194, and 192 mV, respectively). Besides, in all SNX#WPA materials Ei values are higher than those of SNXs (they are in the range of 85–95 mV) used to support WPA. Results obtained for the catalytic evaluation of the prepared materials in the synthesis of DPQX are listed in Table 1. In the absence of catalyst, long reaction times (79 h) are required to achieve quantitative benzil conversion. These reaction conditions are not suitable to carry out the synthesis of DPQX on an industrial scale. The use of bulk WPA as catalyst (Table 1, entry 6) decreases the reaction time to reach 100% conversion (TCB) by almost 90% with respect to the time spent on the blank experiment. So, it is clear that the use of an acid catalyst is necessary to improve reaction time. However, bulk WPA is difficult to isolate and reuse, mainly because it is retained on the surface of the filter used for its separation. When WPA supported on commercial silica (SiO2#WPA) is used (Table 1, entry 7), the conversion considerably improves, with complete benzil conversion being reached after 4.2 h of reaction (synthesis time reduced by half as compared with bulk WPA). Taking into account that SiO2#WPA presents lower acidity than bulk WPA, the decrease of TCB is clearly due to the higher specific surface of the catalyst, which is obtained by supporting WPA on commercial silica. SNPX#WPA materials were subsequently employed as catalysts, reaching a lower TCB than with WPA (TCB decreases between 40 and 70%). As in the case of SiO2#WPA, the SNP#WPA catalysts present lower acidity than bulk WPA, but higher specific surface. On the other hand, the analysis of catalytic performance shows that SNP1#WPA and SNP2#WPA materials with mesopore diameter in the range 5–7 nm and monomodal pore size distribution complete the conversion of benzil at longer times than SNP3#WPA, SNP4#WPA, and SNP5#WPA, which have large mesopores (centered in the range 27–37 nm) additionally to small ones (centered in the range 6–9 nm). Although TCB values are relatively similar, SNP4#WPA, the material with the highest SBET value, presents the lowest TCB values (Table 1, entry 4). Thus these results allow us to conclude that the existence of large mesopores and a high specific surface area are the factors that most influence the catalytic activity of SNPX#WPA materials. Considering that acidic properties of all the synthesized materials are good enough to catalyze the benzil transformation into DBQX, it is possible to suggest that the best catalytic performance of SNP4#WPA is due to the combination of its pore size distribution and specific surface area. The influence of the aforementioned variables is presented in Fig. 4 , where it can be clearly seen that those materials with bimodal PSD (SNP3#WPA, SNP4#WPA, and SNP5#WPA) show a better catalytic performance than those with monomodal PSD (SNP1#WPA and SNP2#WPA). Another pertinent factor is the effect of the catalyst amount on the conversion to DPQX. SNP4#WPA, the catalyst that exhibits the best catalytic performance, was chosen to carry out those tests. This effect was investigated by varying the ratio of SNP4#WPA/benzil in the range of 0.2 to 2% expressed as mol of WPA/mol of benzil. As is shown Table 3 , TCB decreases (compared with the result previously obtained using SNP4#WPA/benzil equal to 0.5%) only by 15 and 35% (Table 3, entries 5 and 6) when the SNP4#WPA/benzyl ratio doubles or quadruples. The TCB reduction is just as minimal considering the huge increment of the catalyst amount employed. Moreover, a catalyst/reactant ratio lower than 0.5% shows to be inadequate (Table 3, entry 1) or less useful (Table 3, entries 2 and 3) to improve the reaction conditions. To evaluate possible WPA solubilization, SNP4#WPA was stirred in toluene for 24 h, filtered, and dried in vacuum till constant weight. TCB of the treated SNP4#WPA catalyst was identical to that of the fresh catalyst. The stirred toluene was used as solvent to evaluate benzil transformation into DBQX without the addition of SNP4#WPA catalyst. The time needed to obtain the complete conversion of the substrate was similar to that for the blank experiment, which allows concluding that there was no appreciable loss of active phase. The absence of WPA leaching was also confirmed by measuring the W content in the stirred toluene by atomic absorption. To study catalytic activity changes during the successive reaction cycles, the reuse of SNP4#WPA was evaluated. The spent catalyst was separated by filtration, dried in a stove at 80 °C, and reused under the same reaction conditions. The results presented in Fig. 5 show that TCB continuously increases with cycles of use. Additionally, the increment is more important after four consecutive reuses. However, when the catalyst is washed with the reaction solvent (1 h, reflux) before its reuse, the reaction time slightly increases until the fifth reuse, to then stay roughly constant (Fig. 5). The catalytic activity decreases with the repeated use, indicating that the catalyst has undergone some type of modification, such as strong adsorption of reagents or products onto the catalytic surface. To clarify this point, a FT-IR analysis of the spent SNP4#WPA catalyst was performed after its use (Fig. 6 ). The FT-IR spectrum of spent SNP4#WPA catalyst (Fig. 6b) reveals the presence of three new bands (at 1534, 957, and 752 cm−1 respectively) overlapping those of the SNP4#WPA material (Fig. 6a). These bands are assigned to the ν C-N (1534 cm−1), ν C-C (952 cm−1), and δ C-H (752 cm−1) modes of 1,2-phenylenediamine [33]. These findings confirm that one of the reagents (1,2-phenylenediamine) remains partially adsorbed on the catalyst after the reaction. On the other hand, the FT-IR spectrum of the spent SNP4#WPA catalyst washed with toluene (Fig. 6c) still shows the aforementioned bands assigned to 1,2-phenylenediamine. However, their intensities are lower than in the unwashed SNP4#WPA catalyst. The spent catalyst was also washed with chloroform, a more polar solvent, but this treatment did not improve 1,2-phenylamine removal (see Fig. S5 and Table S2 in supplementary material). The optimized procedure was extended for the synthesis of DPQX derivatives using different 1,2-ethanodiones and substituted diamine compounds as starting materials, and SNP4#WPA as catalysts. The reactions were performed at 20 °C, using toluene as solvent, and an SNP4#WPA/dione ratio equal to 0.5%. Under these conditions very good yields (all of them higher than 94%) were obtained (Table 4 ). The TLC analysis shows only the DPQX and traces of unreacted diamine (no by-products were detected). After completion of the reaction (complete 1,2-ethanodione conversion monitored by TLC), the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with toluene. After toluene evaporation, the product was easily isolated in almost pure state. Further purification was performed by recrystallization from ethanol. The reaction solvent can be reused after simple distillation. All products were characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy. The characterization details of representative compounds are shown in the Experimental section. Scheme 2 shows a plausible mechanism for quinoxaline synthesis using an acid catalyst according to the mechanism described by Niknam et al. [42]. First, the dione is coordinated to the acid sites of the SNPX#WPA (WPA acts as Brønsted acid), followed by a nucleophilic attack in the carbonyl carbon by the 1,2-phenylenedimine amino groups. Then, the carbocation intermediate is obtained by dehydration and finally, the protons are eliminated to give the quinoxaline, and the catalyst is regenerated. The reactivity of the different substrates was also studied by computational methods. The correlation between the electronic densities of nitrogen atoms in diamines and carbonyl carbon atoms in dione compounds (which were estimated by HyperChem 5.0) and the substrate conversion (reaction time for 100% dione conversion) was analyzed. The electronic densities for diamines, which varied between 0.065 and 0.091, and the dione compounds, which varied between 0.304 and 0.306, are shown in Table 5 . It was observed that diamines 1 and 2 (De = 0.075 and 0.074) are more reactive than diamines 4, 5, and 6 (De = 0.079, 0.081, and 0.090 respectively). The different reactivity of these compounds is associated with the electronic density on the nitrogen atoms, since a higher electronic density (less positive) helps the nucleophilic attack on the electrophilic carbonylic carbon in the dione. As can be seen in Table 5, the existence of an electron-attracting group in 1,2-phenylenediamine, such as a halogen (Table 5, entries 4 and 5), causes an increment in the TCB with respect to non-substituted phenylenediamine (i.e., 2.7 h (Table 5, entry 1) vs. 4.5 h (Table 5, entry 4)). This effect is more remarkable when the aromatic ring presents a heteroatom such as nitrogen (6.5 h in Table 5, entry 6). Moreover, the introduction of a methyl group in ortho position causes an increase in the TCB (8 h in Table 5, entry 3), which is not associated with an electronic effect (De = 0.065) and possibly due to steric hindrance during the nucleophilic attack of the free pairs of electrons of the amino group towards the carbonylic groups of the dione compound. The electronic nature of the substituents in the 1,2-ethanodione compounds was also analyzed. The presence of both electron-attracting (fluorine) and electron-releasing (methyl) substituents causes a significant increase in TCB (Table 5, entries 8 and 9). This considerable increase is not associated with electronic effects since in the case of the three diones the electronic density over carbonylic carbon is practically the same (De = 0.304, 0.305, and 0.306 respectively). Thus it could be associated with the increase in the size of the substrate when incorporating a -CH3 or -F group and its interaction with the pores of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion Acid catalysts based on tungstophosphoric acid immobilized on mesoporous spherical silica nanostructures were prepared using different amounts of octane and styrene. The catalytic activity was evaluated in the synthesis of diphenylquinoxaline, and the best performance (98% yield at 2.7 h, with 0.5% mol (WPA/benzil) ratio) was achieved with SNPX4#WPA, the sample prepared using an OCT/W ratio equal to 0.5 (v/v) and STY/W ratio of 0.39 (w/v), due to the combination of its textural properties and the presence of strong acid sites. SNPX4#WPA presents a specific surface area of 222 m2/g, mesopores centered at 8.6 and 37.0 nm, and an acidity of 194 mV. FT-IR and 31P NMR-MAS results show that WPA remains undegraded and electrostatically interacts with the silanols present on the silica surface. Besides, XRD patterns indicate that WPA is well dispersed on silica nanostructure. SNPX4#WPA reuse assays demonstrated that WPA did not leach into the reaction media. However, the adsorption of phenylenediamine onto the catalyst surface was detected, and washing with fresh toluene was required before its reuse. The procedure was extended successfully for the synthesis of substituted diphenylquinoxalines. The analysis of the substituent electronic density shows that donating groups in phenylenediamine facilitate the nucleophilic attack on the carbonylic carbon. Nevertheless, steric hindrance increases the reaction time when the substituent is in ortho position. The present process constitutes an alternative route for the synthesis of 2,3-diphenylquinoxalines, compounds of interest for their applications as building blocks in the pharmaceutical industry, with excellent yields and optimal reaction times. This constitutes a simple, efficient, selective, and recyclable method. CRediT authorship contribution statement Alexis A. coredata.dc:description: Quinoxalines and their derivatives are of great value in the chemical and biological sciences. These compounds are found in dyes, agrochemicals, and are used as building blocks of drugs for the treatment of different diseases. Quinoxalines and their derivatives are synthesized by a heterogeneous catalysis procedure that involves the condensation of 1,2-dicarbonyl compounds with aromatic 1,2-diamines in an aprotic organic solvent at low temperature, in the presence of an acid catalyst composed of tungstophosphoric acid immobilized on mesoporous silica nanoparticles. The reaction process is very simple and the catalyst, besides being very active and selective, can be easily isolated from the reaction medium and reused in subsequent reactions without considerable loss of activity. Quinoxalines are obtained in short reaction time with excellent yields and high purity.
coredata.dc:title: Tungstophosphoric acid/mesoporous silicas as suitable catalysts in quinoxaline synthesis
